item.label: Cerebral gyri
item.name: Cerebral gyri
item.description: The surface of the cerebral hemispheres is folded or convoluted into cerebral gyri (the elevations) and cerebral sulci (the valleys).

item.label: Cingulate gyrus
item.name: Cingulate gyrus
item.description: The cingulate gyrus is the region of the cerebral cortex that arcs above the corpus callosum on the medial aspect of the hemisphere. Along with the parahippocampal gyrus to which it is connected by the isthmus of the cingulate gyrus, posterior to the splenium of the corpus callosum, it is considered to be the "Limbic lobe" of the brain.

item.label: Paracentral lobule
item.name: Paracentral lobule
item.description: The paracentral lobule is an area of cerebral cortex on the medial aspect of the hemisphere that includes medial extensions of the pre-central (motor) and post-central (somatosensory) gyri. The somatic representation here is for the lower extremity.

item.label: Precuneus
item.name: Precuneus
item.description: The precuneus is that portion of the medial surface of the parietal cerebral cortex, located between the paracentral lobule and the cuneus.

item.label: Cuneus
item.name: Cuneus
item.description: The cuneus gyrus is a wedge-shaped area of occipital cerebral cortex between the parieto-occipital and calcarine sulci. It forms the superior bank of the calcarine sulcus which receives visual input from lower visual fields.

item.label: Lingual gyrus
item.name: Lingual gyrus
item.description: The lingual gyrus forms the inferior bank of the calcarine sulcus. It receives visual input from upper visual fields.

item.label: Cerebral sulci & fissures
item.name: Cerebral sulci_fissures
item.description: A cerebral fissure is AKA a cerebral sulcus (sing.); sulci (pl.).  Fissures are the depressions or grooves between the gyri or convolutions of the cerebral cortex.  Fissure generally refers to a sulcus that is particularly deep.  The terms are used interchangeably in some cases.

item.label: Parieto-occipital sulcus
item.name: Parieto-occipital sulcus
item.description: The parieto-occipital sulcus is a deep fissure that divides the parietal from the occipital lobes on the medial aspect of the cerebral hemisphere.

item.label: Calcarine fissure
item.name: Calcarine fissure
item.description: The calcarine fissure or sulcus is AKA as Area 17 of Brodmann. It is a prominent sulcus on the medial surface of the occipital lobe consisting of an upper bank (cuneus) and lower bank (lingual gyrus) where the neurons of the primary visual cortex are located.

item.label: Lamina terminalis
item.name: Lamina terminalis
item.description: The lamina terminalis is a thin membrane at the rostral end of the third ventricle that represents the original rostral extent of the developing telencephalon. It extends from near the rostrum of the corpus callosum down to the optic chiasm and passes immediately anterior to the anterior commissure.

item.label: Septum Pellucidum
item.name: Septum Pellucidum
item.description: The septum pellucidum is a thin, almost transparent paired membrane that separates the two lateral ventricles. It is stretched out between the area of the septal nuclei and fornix inferiorly and the inferior surface of the corpus callosum.

item.label: Commissures
item.name: Commissures
item.description: The term 'commissure' refers to bundles of axons that cross the midline of the neuraxis and connect corresponding areas of the brain. Significant commissures in the brain are the corpus callosum, anterior and posterior commissures.  In the spinal cord, the anterior or ventral white commissure is very important.

item.label: Corpus Callosum
item.name: Corpus Callosum
item.description: The corpus callosum is a massive curved commissure that interconnects corresponding areas of the two cerebral hemispheres so that these areas may function in a coordinated manner.

item.label: Rostrum
item.name: Rostrum
item.description: The rostrum of the corpus callosum is a thin band of nerve fibers beneath the genu containing commissural fibers interconnecting the orbital cortices.

item.label: Genu
item.name: Genu
item.description: The genu is the sharp bend in the corpus callosum at it most anterior or rostral aspect.  The commissural fibers within the genu interconnect the frontal lobes.

item.label: Body
item.name: Body
item.description: The body is the main portion of the corpus callosum containing commissural fibers which distribute extensively between the two hemispheres.

item.label: Splenium
item.name: Splenium
item.description: The splenium is the thick and rounded posterior aspect of the corpus callosum.  These commissural axons interconnect the occipital and temporal regions of the cerebral hemispheres.

item.label: Anterior commissure
item.name: Anterior commissure
item.description: The anterior commissure is a small and compact bundle of commissural axons located just beneath and caudal to the rostrum of the corpus callosum. It connects corresponding areas in the temporal cortices as well as olfactory structures.

item.label: Posterior Commissure
item.name: Posterior Commissure
item.description: The posterior commissure consists of nerve fibers that interconnect the two sides of the rostral midbrain and pretectum. These fibers are involved in the consensual aspect of the pupillary light reflex and in coordinating vertical eye movements.

item.label: Fornix
item.name: Fornix
item.description: The fornix is a compact bundle of axons, primarily efferents from the hippocampus to the ipsilateral septal nuclei and hypothalamus. Parts of the fornix from the hippocampus and beyond are the fimbria, crus, body and column.

item.label: Diencephalon
item.name: Diencephalon
item.description: Developmentally, the diencephalon and telencephalon are derived from the most anterior aspect of the developing neural tube, i.e. the prosencephalon. It includes the thalamus, hypothalamus, epithalamus and subthalamus. The retina, optic nerve and tract and neurohypophysis are also considered to be part of the diencephalon since they are formed as outgrowths from the diencephalon.

item.label: Thalamus
item.name: Thalamus
item.description: The thalamus is a large collection of nuclei that have major connections with the cerebral cortex involving both sensory and motor functions. Some thalamic nuclei have very specific connections relative to visual, auditory and somatosensory afferents and their projection to specific areas of cerebral cortex, while other nuclei have more general inputs and connections with association areas of cerebral cortex.

item.label: Hypothalamus
item.name: Hypothalamus
item.description: The hypothalamus is the most inferior of the four divisions of the diencephalon. While quite small, it has multiple important functions. It is the central control center for the autonomic nervous system, part of the limbic system, exerts a powerful influence on pituitary function and generally is responsible for maintaining homeostasis. It consists of multiple nuclei organized into three regions: anterior (suprachiasmatic, supraoptic and paraventricular), tuberal (dorsomedial, ventromedial and arcuate) and posterior (mammillary and posterior).

item.label: Mammillary Body
item.name: Mammillary Body
item.description: The mammillary bodies are part of the posterior hypothalamus.  They appear from the ventral view of the brain as a pair of rounded elevations. Primary circuitry involves input from the hippocampus via the fornix and output to the anterior nucleus of thalamus via the mammillothalamic tract. They are part of the Papez circuitry of the limbic system.

item.label: Epithalamus, Pineal gland
item.name: Epithalamus Pineal gland
item.description: The pineal gland is the part of the epithalamus that extends caudally from the area of the habenular nuclei and into the superior cistern, immediately dorsal to the superior colliculi. As an endocrine gland, it secretes melatonin and is involved with circadian rhythms and the sleep-wake cycle.

item.label: Pituitary
item.name: Pituitary
item.description: The pituitary gland is AKA the hypophysis. The master gland through which the hypothalamus controls most other endocrine glands. The posterior lobe and the infundibulum or pituitary stalk that attaches it to the medial eminence of the hypothalamus are collectively termed the neurohypophysis; they arise embryologically as a ventral outgrowth from the diencephalon. The supraoptic and paraventricular nuclei of the hypothalamus release oxytocin and vasopressin into the bloodstream in the neurohypophysis. The anterior lobe or adenophypophysis secretes a variety of hormones that control other endocrine glands but is itself under the control of releasing and inhibiting hormones secreted by the hypothalamus. It is formed embryologically from the roof of the oral cavity (Rathke's pouch).

item.label: Visual pathway, Optic Chiasm
item.name: Visual pathway Optic Chiasm
item.description: The optic chiasm is a midline structure that consists of the axons of retinal neurons located in the nasal half of each retina.  These nerve fibers travel first in the optic nerve and then cross in midline of the optic chiasm so that the input from the nasal retina of each eye (temporal visual field) projects to the contralateral optic tract and beyond in the visual pathway. Input from the temporal retina (nasal visual field) does NOT cross in the chiasm but projects through the ipsilateral visual pathway.  This partial crossing of the visual input is essential for binocular vision.

item.label: Midbrain
item.name: Midbrain
item.description: The midbrain is AKA the mesencephalon. Within its parts (tectum, tegmentum, substantia nigra and cerebral crus or basis pedunculi), it contains cranial nerve nuclei, all of the clinically important ascending and descending tracts, etc. It is traversed by the cerebral aqueduct or aqueduct of Sylvius. It originates developmentally from the mesencephalon.

item.label: Tectum
item.name: Tectum
item.description: The tectum is that portion of the midbrain located above the cerebral aqueduct.  It includes the superior and inferior colliculi which are AKA the quadrigeminal bodies.

item.label: Tegmentum
item.name: Tegmentum
item.description: The tegmentum is that portion of the midbrain that lies between the cerebral aqueduct and the crus cerebri.  It includes the major ascending sensory tracts (medial lemniscus, spinothalamic), the red nucleus and the substantia nigra.

item.label: Pons
item.name: Pons
item.description: The pons is that portion of the brainstem between the midbrain and medulla. It consists of a basilar or basal portion that contains structures primarily associated with motor control and a tegmental portion that contains cranial nerve nuclei and important sensory tracts. The cerebellum overlies the pons and medulla. The rostral aspect of the fourth ventricle is located on the dorsal surface of the pons. The pons and cerebellum originate embryologically from the metencephalon of the hindbrain.

item.label: Tegmentum
item.name: Tegmentum_1
item.description: The tegmentum or tegmental pons forms the dorsal aspect of the pons.  It is continuous with the tegmental portions of both the midbrain and medulla. Includes cranial nerve nuclei and clinically important sensory tracts [medial lemniscal, spinothalamic, lateral lemniscal]. The rostral aspect of the fourth ventricle is located on it dorsal surface.

item.label: Basilar
item.name: Basilar
item.description: The basilar pons is AKA the basal pons. It is the ventral portion of the pons that includes the following important elements that are primarily involved in motor control: corticospinal, corticobulbar, corticospinal and pontocerebellar tracts plus the pontine nuclei. Thus, it serves as a conduit for descending motor pathways from cerebral cortex to the pons, medulla and spinal cord. In addition, it connects the cerebral cortex with the cerebellum via synapses of the corticopontine fibers on pontine nuclei that then give origin to the pontocerebellar fibers which terminate in cerebellum.

item.label: Medulla
item.name: Medulla
item.description: The medulla is AKA the medulla oblongata. The most caudal aspect of the brain stem, it is located between the pons and spinal cord. It contains structures vital to survival such as cardiovascular and respiratory centers, as well as many cranial nerve nuclei. The major ascending and descending tracts travel through it between the spinal cord and higher centers. It originates developmentally from the myelencephalon of the hindbrain.

item.label: Cerebellum, Vermis
item.name: Cerebellum, vermis
item.description: The vermis of the cerebellum is the most medial region, i.e. the narrow midline section associated with the anterior, posterior and flocculonodular lobes of the cerebellum.

item.label: Anterior lobe
item.name: Anterior lobe
item.description: The anterior lobe of the cerebellum is that portion of the cerebellum anterior to the primary fissure, including parts of the vermis and hemisphere.

item.label: Primary fissure
item.name: Primary fissure
item.description: The primary fissure of the cerebellum separates the anterior lobe from the posterior lobe of the cerebellum. It extends into both the vermal and hemispheric aspects of the cerebellum.

item.label: Posterior lobe
item.name: Posterior lobe
item.description: The posterior lobe of the cerebellum is that portion between the primary and posterolateral fissures.  It includes parts of the vermis and hemispheres.

item.label: Posterolateral fissure
item.name: Posterolateral fissure
item.description: The posterolateral fissure of the cerebellum separates the posterior lobe from the flocculonodular lobe of the cerebellum. It extends into both the vermal and hemispheric aspects of the cerebellum.

item.label: Nodule
item.name: Nodule
item.description: The nodule or nodulus of the cerebellum is a small portion of the ventral and anterior vermis that is attached to the flocculus to form the flocculonodular lobe. Functionally, the flocculonodular lobe is associated with balance as well as movements of the eyes.

item.label: Cerebellum, Hemisphere, Tonsil
item.name: Cerebellum, tonsil
item.description: The tonsils of the cerebellum are the medial, inferior part of the posterior lobe of each cerebellar hemisphere, adjacent to the medulla and near the foramen magnum. The tonsils are of clinical significance since they may herniate through the foramen magnum with increased intracranial pressure.

item.label: Spinal cord
item.name: Spinal cord
item.description: The spinal cord is that portion of the central nervous system that extends from the medulla to the conus medullaris. It consists of 31 segments (8 cervical, 12 thoracic, 5 lumbar, 5 sacral, 1 coccygeal) and has enlargements at the levels serving the limbs (C5 - T1 and L2 - S3).

item.label: Arteries, branches of
item.name: Arteries_branches of
item.description: The arterial supply to the brain is via the paired internal carotid and vertebral arteries. The terminal branches of the internal carotid arteries are the paired anterior and middle cerebral arteries which supply supratentorial structures.  The two vertebral arteries enter the cranial cavity via the foramen magnum; they join one another at the junction of the medulla with the pons to form the basilar artery.  Together the vertebral-basilar system of arteries supplies the structures of the posterior fossa as well as those supratentorial structures supplied by its terminal branches -- the posterior cerebral arteries.

item.label: Anterior cerebral
item.name: Anterior cerebral
item.description: The anterior cerebral artery is the most anterior of the terminal branches of the internal carotid artery. Along with its branches, it curves around the genu and then superior to the corpus callosum to supply the orbital gyri, medial aspect of the frontal lobe, a portion of the parietal lobe and a narrow band along the most superior region of the lateral aspect of the hemisphere. Since the anterior cerebral artery supplies the paracentral lobule which is responsible for sensation and motor control of the contralateral lower extremity, loss of this blood supply results in paralysis and loss of sensation in the contralateral lower extremity.

item.label: Vertebral
item.name: Vertebral
item.description: Along with the internal carotid arteries, the vertebral arteries are the major blood supply to the brain. The two vertebral arteries fuse at the junction of the medulla and pons to form the basilar artery. The vertebral-basilar system supplies structures in the posterior fossa plus posterior aspects of the diencephalon, choroid plexus in the third and lateral ventricles and the medial and inferior surfaces of the occipital and temporal lobes of the cerebral hemispheres.

item.label: Basilar
item.name: Basilar_1
item.description: The two vertebral arteries fuse at the junction of the medulla and pons to form the basilar artery. At the junction of the pons and midbrain, the basilar bifurcates into two terminal branches, the posterior cerebral arteries. Branches of the basilar & posterior cerebral arteries supply parts of the brain stem, cerebellum, posterior aspects of the diencephalon, choroid plexus in the third and lateral ventricles and the medial and inferior surfaces of the occipital and temporal lobes of the cerebral hemispheres.

item.label: Superior cerebellar
item.name: Superior cerebellar
item.description: The superior cerebellar artery is a branch from the basilar artery just caudal to the bifurcation of the basilar to form the two posterior cerebral arteries. It supplies the superior aspect of the cerebellum plus parts of the caudal midbrain and rostral pons.

item.label: Posterior cerebral
item.name: Posterior cerebral
item.description: The posterior cerebral arteries are paired vessels formed as the terminal branches of the basilar artery at the level of the midbrain. They are part of the posterior aspect of the circle of Willis and supply the rostral midbrain, posterior thalamus, medial occipital lobe as well as the inferior and medial surfaces of the temporal lobe. Disruption of the posterior cerebral artery may result in blindness in the contralateral visual field since it supplies the visual cortex of the occipital lobe; it may also present as a contralateral upper motor neuron lesion with spastic paralysis of the contralateral body and face as well as an ipsilateral lower motor neuron lesion of the oculomotor nerve/nucleus since it supplies the crus cerebri and oculumotor nerve/nucleus in the midbrain.

item.label: Cerebral veins, deep
item.name: Cerebral veins, deep
item.description: Cerebral veins drain the blood from the brain into the venous sinus system which, in turn, drains into the internal jugular veins.  These cerebral veins are described as superficial or deep, depending on whether they drain the superficial or deep aspects of the brain.

item.label: Internal cerebral
item.name: Internal cerebral
item.description: The internal cerebral veins are paired, deep cerebral veins.  These major veins drain most of the interior of the brain. Formed at the level of the interventricular foramen of Monro by the union of the thalamostriate and choroidal veins, they travel posteriorly to the area of the superior or quadrigeminal cistern where they unite and join the Great Vein of Galen.

item.label: Great cerebral
item.name: Great cerebral
item.description: The great cerebral vein of Galen is AKA the vein of Galen or the great vein of Galen. It is a large, unpaired vein formed by the union of the two internal cerebral veins within the superior or quadrigeminal cistern. It also receives the basal veins of Rosenthal before it curves around the splenium of the corpus callosum and joins the inferior sagittal sinus at its junction with the straight sinus within the tentorium cerebelli.

item.label: Dural venous sinuses
item.name: Dural venous sinuses
item.description: The dural venous sinuses are endothelial-lined spaces between the periosteal and meningeal layers of the dura.  They form where the meningeal layer of the dura is reflected away from the surface of the skull and into the spaces between parts of the brain such as the longitudinal fissure.  Included are the superior sagittal, inferior sagittal, straight, transverse, occipital, sigmoid, cavernous, superior petrosal, and inferior petrosal sinuses.  Most of the blood from the brain empties into these sinuses before draining into the internal jugular veins and leaving the cranium.

item.label: Superior sagittal
item.name: Superior sagittal
item.description: The superior sagittal sinus of the dural venous sinus system is located in the superior midline of the cerebral dura and thus, in the superior, attached edge of the cerebral falx. It receives venous blood from cerebral, diploic and emissary veins and joins the remainder of the sinus system at the confluence in the sinuses near the internal occipital protuberance.

item.label: Straight
item.name: Straight
item.description: The straight sinus of the dural venous sinus system that is located in the midline region of the tentorium cerebelli. The great cerebral vein of Galen and the basal vein empty into it and the straight sinus, in turn, drains into the confluence of the venous sinuses.

item.label: Confluence
item.name: Confluence
item.description: The confluence of the dural sinuses is the convergence point of the superior sagittal, straight, occipital and transverse sinuses near the occipital protuberance.

item.label: Occipital
item.name: Occipital
item.description: The occipital dural venous sinus is located in the attached border of the cerebellar falx and ends superiorly in the confluence of the sinuses.  It communicates inferiorly with the internal vertebral venous plexus.

item.label: Ventricular system
item.name: Ventricular system
item.description: The ventricular system is a series of interconnected cerebrospinal-filled chambers within the cerebral hemispheres. Cerebrospinal fluid is formed in the choroid plexus located in the lateral, third and fourth ventricles.

item.label: Interventricular Foramen
item.name: Interventricular Foramen
item.description: The interventricular foramen is AKA the foramen of Monro. The paired interventricular foramina are channels for cerebrospinal flow from each lateral ventricle to the third ventricle.

item.label: CSF flow artifact
item.name: CSF flow artifact
item.description: CSF flow artifact appears as a bright area in narrowed regions of the ventricular system on the MRI images.  It is due to the flow of the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) through these narrowed areas.

item.label: Third Ventricle
item.name: Third Ventricle
item.description: The third ventricle is a single, narrow, vertically-oriented portion of the ventricular system.  It is located between the two halves of the thalamus and hypothalamus.

item.label: Cerebral Aqueduct
item.name: Cerebral Aqueduct
item.description: The cerebral aqueduct is AKA the cerebral aqueduct of Sylvius.  It is a narrow channel within the midbrain through which cerebrospinal fluid flows from the third ventricle into the fourth ventricle.

item.label: Fourth Ventricle
item.name: Fourth Ventricle
item.description: The fourth ventricle is a rhomboid-shaped space located superior to the pons and medulla. The roof of the fourth ventricle is formed by the inferior and superior medullary vela plus the cerebellum. Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) enters the fourth ventricle from the third ventricle via the cerebral aqueduct. CSF exits the fourth ventricle into the subarachnoid space via the medial foramen of Magendie, located in the roof of the fourth ventricle, and the two lateral foramina of Luschka, located at the most lateral aspect of the fourth ventricle, i.e. in the lateral recess of the fourth ventricle, bilaterally.  The choroid plexus is located in the roof of the fourth ventricle, beneath the inferior medullary velum.  The choroid plexus extends outside of the fourth ventricle through the foramina of Luschka, where it can be visualized in the subarachnoid space.

item.label: Superior medullary velum
item.name: Superior medullary velum
item.description: The superior medullary velum is a thin layer of white matter that stretched between the paired superior cerebellar peduncles.  Along with the superior cerebellar peduncles, it forms part of the roof of the fourth ventricle.

item.label: Cisterns, Subarachnoid
item.name: Cisterns, subarachnoid
item.description: Within the skull there are some places - particularly at the base of the brain where the subarachnoid space is widened to form large pools of cerebrospinal fluid called the subarachnoid cisterns.  They communicate freely with one another, as well as with the remainder of the subarachnoid space surrounding the brain and spinal cord.  The major cisterns are the cerebellomedullary (AKA cisterna magna), pontine, interpeduncular and superior (AKA quadrigeminal) cisterns.

item.label: Cisterna magna
item.name: Cisterna magna
item.description: The cisterna magna is AKA the cerebellomedullary cistern. It is a very large subarachnoid cistern located between the medulla and the inferior aspect of the cerebellum.

item.label: Interpeduncular
item.name: Interpeduncular
item.description: The interpeduncular cistern is a cerebrospinal fluid-filled subarachnoid space located between the cerebral peduncles on the inferior surface of the midbrain, i.e. the interpeduncular fossa, and extending rostrally beneath the diencephalon.

item.label: Quadrigeminal
item.name: Quadrigeminal
item.description: The superior cistern is AKA the quadrigeminal cistern or the cistern of the great cerebral vein. It is subarachnoid space located above the midbrain that is continuous with the transverse fissure. It is an important radiologic landmark since the pineal gland can be visualized within its midline location.
